title: Pope warns powerful to act humbly or risk ruin in TED talk
title_page: Pope warns powerful to act humbly or risk ruin in TED talk | Daily Mail Online
text:
Pope Francis has made a surprise appearance at a TED talk, urging world leaders to 'act with humility and tenderness'.
The pontiff delivered an 18-minute videotaped talk to a TED conference in Vancouver on 'The Future You' on Tuesday - the first to be delivered by a pope.
In the sermon, he warned that power is 'like drinking gin on an empty stomach', and said that leaders and politicians did not 'exclusively' control the future of humankind.

Speaking in Italian from behind a desk, he began: 'Please allow me to say it loud and clear.
'The more powerful you are, the more your actions will have an impact on people, the more you are called to be humble.
'If you don't, your power will ruin you, and you will ruin others.'
He added that there is a saying in Argentina that 'power is like drinking gin on an empty stomach'.
'You feel dizzy, you get drunk, you lose your balance and you will end up hurting yourself and those around you if you don't connect your power with humility and tenderness.
'Through humility and concrete love on the other hand, power - the highest, strongest one - becomes a service, a force for good.
'The future of humankind isn't exclusively in the hands of politicians, of great leaders, of big companies.
He warned that power is 'like drinking gin on an empty stomach', and said that leaders and politicians did not 'exclusively' control the future of humankind
Francis also pleaded for greater solidarity to be considered in political, economic and scientific endeavors
He said people feel 'dizzy, drunk and lose their balance' when they have too much power
'Yes, they do hold enormous responsibility, but the future is most of all in the hands of those people who recognise the other as "you" and themselves as part of an "us".
'We all need each other. So please, think of me as well with tenderness so that I can fulfill the task that I have been given for the good of the other - of each and every one. Of all of you, of all of us.'
Francis also pleaded for greater solidarity to be considered in political, economic and scientific endeavors.
He said that technological innovation is fine, but not when it blinds society to the people suffering around us.
'How wonderful would it be, while we discover faraway planets, to rediscover the needs of the brothers and sisters orbiting around us,' he said.
'How wonderful would it be if solidarity - this beautiful and sometimes inconvenient word - were not simply reduced to social work and became instead the default attitude in political, economic and scientific choices.'
The Pope added that he liked the title of the TED conference, because it opens up a dialogue about the future.
But he also said that we can only achieve our goals by working together.
'Quite a few years of life have strengthened my conviction that each and everyone's existence is deeply tied to that of others,' Francis said. 'Life is not time merely passing by, life is about interactions.'

Despite having 10million Twitter followers on Twitter, the 80-year-old churchman warned that technological innovation could blind people to the suffering around them
The Pope said he often thinks about his grandparents - migrants from Italy who moved to Argentina.
He said he wonders how they would have fared among the 'culture of waste' in today's unforgiving world.
'I could have very well ended up among today's 'discarded' people. And that's why I always ask myself, deep in my heart: 'Why them and not me?''
He continued: 'A single individual is enough for hope to exist, and that individual can be you. And then there will be another 'you,' and another 'you,' and it turns into an 'us.'
'And so, does hope begin when we have an 'us?' No. Hope began with one 'you.' When there is an 'us,' there begins a revolution.'
TED, short for Technology, Entertainment and Design, organizes conferences around the world aiming to spread ideas through short talks.
Francis' participation in the TED conference marked a new era for the Vatican's communications operation, which has increasingly sought to get the pope's message out via social media and nontraditional news sources.
In the video, released by the Vatican on Wednesday, took more than a year of convincing.
Bruno Giusanni, TED's international curator, coaxed Francis into recording a talk - viewing him as a 'moral voice' with a clear message.
'In this complicated and often confusing world, Pope Francis has become possibly the only moral voice capable of reaching people across boundaries and providing clarity and a compelling message of hope,' he told CNN.
